results.title: Battle for Warsaw
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Visions of War”.
This new documentary special traces the tragic story of the 1944 Warsaw uprising in which nearly a quarter of a million Poles lost their lives. It includes much archive material that is rare, and that has only recently come to light; as well as remarkable eye-witness accounts from some of the principals. Rated: PG

results.title: Battle for the Bulge
results.creator_credit: Peter Batty and Peter Batty Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Visions of War”.
December 1944 witnessed the last German offensive of the Second World War. The Battle of the Bulge, as this campaign in the Ardennes forests of Belgium and Luxembourg is now more familiarly known, was the biggest single pitched battle of the Western Front - more than a million troops took part. It was Hitler’s most desperate gamble of the war, he in fact planned its every move. This film uses current location filming and authentic historical film clips to document this battle. Portrays the heroism, as well as the confusion and humiliation, that characterised both the Allied and German troops.

results.title: Banjo's Australia
results.brief_description: This program explains A. B. Paterson’s contribution and significance to Australian literature from the 1890’s to the World War I. It traces Paterson’s personal history, his love of the bush, his admiration for camaraderie and spirit of the bush and the pathos and humour of bush life.

results.title: All under heaven: life in a chinese village
results.creator_credit: Richard Gordon, Carma Hinton, Don Sape, Kathy Kline and Long Bow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Long Bow Trilogy”.
An intimate look at daily life in Long Bow, a village 600 kilometres south-west of Beijing in Northern China. Ancient traditions persist - we see an elaborate funeral, a country fair, a local animal market and an open air opera. Documents the changes that have come to Long Bow with the shift from collective to individual farming.

results.title: Small happiness : Life in a Chinese village
results.creator_credit: Richard Gordon, Carma Hinton and Long Bow Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Long Bow Trilogy”.
Despite the tremendous advances women in China have made, serious problems continue. Long Bow women talk about love, marriage, work, birth control, birth customs and the now outlawed custom of foot binding. Moving interviews with Ling Qiao and her mother-in-law draw us into their lives.

results.title: How the west was lost: the story of the 1946 Aboriginal pastoral workers' strike
results.creator_credit: David Noakes, Heather Williams, Market Street Films and Friends Film Productions
results.brief_description: The story of the 1946 Aboriginal Pastoral Workers’ Strike. Eight hundred aboriginal station workers walked off sheep stations in the north west of Western Australia, marking the beginning of a strike which lasted more than three years. The strike was more than a demand for better wages and conditions, it was a struggle for basic human rights.
results.title_for_label: How the west was lost: the story of the 1946 Aboriginal pastoral workers’ strike

results.title: Building dreams
results.creator_credit: Yuri Sokol, Michael Le Moignan and Corroboree Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Black futures (A)”.
Until recently, the 150,000 Australians who are of Aboriginal descent had little hope of ever owning a home or getting a permanent job. Now, young Aboriginal building apprentices are putting up first class new homes for their own communities. Better living conditions are helping Aboriginal people to maintain their own distinct sense of identity and boosting their self-confidence.

results.title: Genesis (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Horizon”.
A joint British/US program unravelling the mysteries of nature. Genesis journeys through the world of embryology to discover the intricate mechanisms by which all animal life, from insect to human, is formed.

results.title: Political power
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
There are four themes providing some answers to important questions. Who holds power in Australia? How is it distributed? What conflicts arise through the unequal distribution of power? How is it resolved? What means do Australians have to influence the decision making process? Presented by Annette Shun Wah.

results.title: Beliefs, values and customs
results.creator_credit: Greg Reading, Jan Punch and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Film Australia’s Australia”.
In order to cover some of the great diversity of Australian life over the years, 12 one-hour titles have been produced. “Beliefs, Values and Customs” is Part One of the two-part Cultural Environment and examines Aboriginal culture, the religions of Australia, the British heritage, a multicultural society , the influences of the mass media and advertising the Aussie image, sport, language and communication.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Greg Reading, Jan Punch and Film Australia
